content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-049-14-B |Item_parent=Normal and pathological puberty |Item_parent_short=Normal and pathological puberty |Rank=B |Title=Knowing the precise etiologies of early puberty |Description=None |Rubric=Etiologies |Contributors= |Order=14}} {| class="wikitable" | '''early central PP'''' | |- | Intracranial process | Tumour: chiasma glioma (NF1 or not), hamartoma Non-tumoral: hydrocephalus, arachnoid cyst |- | Sequelae | Meningitis or encephalitis Cranial irradiation |- |Idiopathic |Diagnosis of elimination |- | '''Peripheral PP''' | |- | Ovarian/testicular | McCune-Albright, ovarian cyst, granulosa tumour Testotoxicosis |- | Adrenal | Hyperandrogenism without gonadotropic activation Adrenal cortex |- |Exogenous '''Environmental''' '''Genetics''' | |}

question.title: What is the most common cause of early puberty in girls?
